visuals.title: PacMan_Unchained
visuals.description:
Pacman has been taken out of the maze, and he brought friends. 

Sadly, they don't know how to handle their new found freedom and find themselves being eradicated by a single red ghost. The ghost is eating them and excreting... cherries? And doing so is draining his undead... life.. force?

Too bad their escape was doomed from the start. Pacman and friends are not able to handle the Earth's atmosphere and will be glitching dead in ten seconds time supposing any are left. (We never even saw war of the worlds, what are you talking about?)

visuals.title: Frozen brush
visuals.description:
Inspired by Makio135's sketch: www.openprocessing.org/sketch/385808

Makes use of a delaunay algorithm to create crystal-like shapes.
I did NOT develop delaunay.js, and not sure who the author really is to give proper credit.

visuals.title: Volcanic cascades
visuals.description:
A combination of my two older sketches:
Waterfall cascades: https://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/396286
Frozen brush: https://www.openprocessing.org/sketch/413567

Uses the physics from the waterfall sketch, and renders it with delaunay triangulation.
I did NOT develop delaunay.js, and not sure who the author really is to give proper credit.

Controls:
  - Move the mouse around to interact with the particles.
  - Use the on-screen controls to effect the sim.

visuals.title: Random Rectangles
visuals.description: Random Rectangles is a code that changes multiple parameters of a rectangle every time the function is called. The parameters include the width, length, X and Y origin coordinates, thickness of the outline, and whether the rectangle is filled or not filled. The user can change the amount of rectangles drawn, the size of the canvas, and the upper and lower bounds of other previously stated parameters. Furthermore, the code refreshes to draw new rectangles every time the user clicks the canvas. Thus, you can have a new rectangular design in a matter of seconds!

visuals.title: Glow
visuals.description:
Simple glow effect. 

1. draw things on the screen.
2. draw the same things again on the screen, blurred and with blend mode ADD.

Note: in processing.js there is an unexpected offset (glow is moved up and left). I fixed this by offsetting the blend() by 6 pixels.

In recent Processing IDEs you can use blendMode() + image() instead of blend().

visuals.title: aSketch9_noPDF
visuals.description:
Earlier this year, I developed the new brand identity for AgilOne, in which patterns play a singular role: http://yagmourian.com/gaston/projects/agilone

Each mouse click triggers an algorithm to redraw the pattern, based on rules established in the code: a defined set of shapes is arranged in a grid and colored with the brand colours.

Coding brings endless possibilities to brand identity and design in general. I'm excited about incorporating it more into my practice as I keep gaining knowledge.

visuals.title: Disco Hall
visuals.description:
Interface:
click to create a new disco (does not change outline toggle)
o - toggle outline
i - toggle irregular quads
s - creates new shapes
p - randomizes the rotation speeds
m - cycles through color modes (two tone, alternating, hardlight, softlight)
c - randomizes the colors
left and right arrows - change the alpha of the rays (only has an affect in hardlight and softlight modes)
a - toggle smooth. turn it off if the program is running too slowly on your system

Ideas for future expansion: 
 -ray size control
 -irregular ellipses
 -polygons other than quads
 -more color modes

visuals.title: Voronoi Tessellation at runtime
visuals.description:
"A Voronoi diagram is a partitioning of a plane into regions based on 'closeness' to points in a specific subset of the plane. For each seed there is a corresponding region consisting of all points closer to that seed than to any other."

Click on the screen to create a new point.
For every point, we calculate and show a Voronoi tessellation.

Cursor to the bottom: thicker strokes, smaller alpha 

Apparently, this application works on Android browsers.

University of London / International Programmes

visuals.title: 10 PRINT: Image Dithering
visuals.description:
This sketch creates a 10PRINT-dithered image of Casey Reas, creator of Processing and author of the book "10 PRINT CHR$(205.5+RND(1)); : GOTO 10"

The randomness used to create the labyrinth pattern is taken from the image source.
 
Move the mouse left for maximum randomness
(sampling the least significant bits)

Move the mouse right for minimum randomness
(sampling the most significant bits)
 
Press any key to switch between resolutions.

visuals.title: Glitch Effect
visuals.description:
A simple glitch effect that I applied to an image made in Apophysis 7x.

===== Instructions =====

Wait a few seconds for it to load.

Press Control to generate a new image (you might have to click the canvas for key presses to get detected).

Press and hold the mouse button to show the original image.

Press Space to save a snapshot of the current image.
visuals.instructions:
Wait a few seconds for it to load.

Press Control to generate a new image (you might have to click the canvas for key presses to get detected).

Press and hold the mouse button to show the original image.

Press Space to save a snapshot of the current image (doesn't include the preview in the top-left corner).

visuals.title: Pixel to time
visuals.description:
The program scans an image in order to check each of its pixel's value. Pixels of the screen can be randomly either white or black, but the darker a pixel value of the image is, the more often it will be displayed in black on the screen.

french : ce programme scanne une image pour vérifier la luminosité de chacun de ses pixels. À l'écran, chaque pixel peut être affiché en noir ou en blanc selon un hasard qui est conditionné à la luminosité de l'image de départ. Donc un point noir de l'image aura x fois plus de chances d'être affiché en noir qu'un point blanc.

visuals.title: Noise flow field painter
visuals.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:
  - Click to change to the next image.
  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.
visuals.instructions: Click for the next image, press a key to save a jpg.

forks.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:
  - Click to change to the next image.
  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.
forks.instructions: Click for the next image, press a key to save a jpg.

visuals.title: 噪音流场画家
visuals.description: *可能需要片刻加载*使用由噪声驱动的流场旋转的笔划绘制图像。如果要在自己的图像上进行尝试，则需要在草图的文件选项卡中拖放图像。然后将图像的文件名添加到变量imgNames（它靠近顶部）。它不能很好地捕捉细节，因此近距离效果最佳。控制： - 单击以切换到下一个图像。 - 按任意键将画布保存为jpg。
visuals.instructions: 单击下一个图像，按一个键保存jpg。

visuals.title: Hyperbolic Coral
visuals.description:
Kerrin Jefferis and Patrick Stein - Computational Nature Study for Generative Design (Masters of Digital Design, University of Canberra) 

A hyperbolic coral generator inspired by a similar system using crochet exhibited by the Institute for Figuring: http://crochetcoralreef.org/

Press any key to generate new coral, and use mouse to navigate view (left click drag to rotate, right click to zoom).

Further documentation: http://x-polis.blogspot.com.au/2011/04/hyperbolic-coral.html

visuals.title: Simple Physics
visuals.instructions:
Left click to add a new node.
Right click to reset.

visuals.title: 3D Delaunay Triangulation
visuals.description:
与えられた点からメッシュを作る練習として、1年生の頃に作ったプログラムです。

クリックするたびに、以下のように状態が変化します。
・ 与えられたランダムな点群
・ それを基にした 3次元 Delaunay 分割
・ 内部エッジの除去
・ サーフェスの生成

visuals.title: aSketch9_noPDF
visuals.description:
Earlier this year, I developed the new brand identity for AgilOne, in which patterns play a singular role: http://yagmourian.com/gaston/projects/agilone

Each mouse click triggers an algorithm to redraw the pattern, based on rules established in the code: a defined set of shapes is arranged in a grid and colored with the brand colours.

Coding brings endless possibilities to brand identity and design in general. I'm excited about incorporating it more into my practice as I keep gaining knowledge.

visuals.title: fade in / fade out
visuals.instructions: mouse

visuals.title: Islamic Stars
visuals.description:
Move the mouse horizontally and vertically to change the image.  X and Y control two different parameters.

This was an experiment with a method used to produce Arabic/Islamic star tiling patterns, from an underlying grid of polygons.

Starting with an underlying grid of polygons, the star pattern is produced by drawing lines from two equidistant points on each polygon edge at some fixed angle (controlled by the mouse).  At the point where the lines would intersect with other lines, they are clipped.

Y controls the distance from the center of the polygon edge.
X controls angle.

visuals.title: Lindenmayer Plants
visuals.description:
Finally had some time to extend my old l-system project. Check tutorial for general explanations: http://paulbourke.net/fractals/lsys/. This time most replacement rules consist of sets of possible replacements which are chosen randomly within a given likelihood. The axiom and the replacements (with their likelihoods) are written on the bottom of the drawing:

Controls:
Click with mouse = new random plant
Space = same plant with new random values
Left/ Right Arrow = increase / decrease angle
Plus / Minus = add / remove  iteration (don't add too much iterations)
t = show / hide text

visuals.title: Rorschach Generator
visuals.description:
To see how this works, hit 'f' to disable the filter. You'll see that the balls are darkest at the center and lightest at the outside. The filter gets rid of everything lighter than the threshold, and turns everything else black. 


controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

visuals.title: Creative Coding Final: Pointillism 花花
visuals.description:
This p5.js creative coding project is inspired by the 19th-century modern art movement -- Pointillism --a technique of painting in which small, distinct dots of color are applied in patterns to form an image. This project simulates an interactive exhibition experience, in which the user, together with the author,
recreates some of the most well-known Pointillism artwork with modern technology. The look of the final artwork not only depends on the code itself, but also the user's interactive control of
the size of the paint stroke.

visuals.title: Maze Generator: Randomized Kruskal's Algorithm迷宫
visuals.description:
Another maze generation program. This is one is a lot less fun than the last one but the code is a lot tidier and there is now a working solver. 

For more resources on Kruskal's algorithm, see:
* http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2011/1/3/maze-generation-kruskal-s-algorithm
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maze_generation_algorithm#Randomized_Kruskal's_algorithm
Basically, it puts the cells into sets, which are all merged (by removing a wall between them) until all the cells are connected. The colors you see are the sets.

Kruskal's algorithm generates perfect mazes with a uniform spanning tree.
visuals.instructions: Use the controls on the right. See description for more info.

visuals.title: Blue Mountains
visuals.description:
A mountain range landscape.

Inspired by lesson 38 of Fun Programming: http://funprogramming.org/38-Animate-the-ocean-surface-using-noise.html 

Colors chosen to work on Javascript (the clouds and the sky gradient look different on Java mode). Also, I don't know why, the lerpColor didn't work on Java, it's possible to get the same effect with separated map functions for hue, saturation and brightness though. - Barbara Almeida

Adjusted the mountains to start ~ 1/3 from the top. The rule of thirds is a good guide to where major divisions should lie in a painting or photograph. - Richard B
visuals.instructions:
Mouse click to generate a new pattern.
Press s to save as an image.

visuals.title: ImageTexter
visuals.description:
A text-painter, with color coming (primarily) from 4 possible images.
Try painting a grid, reducing the size, and painting again!

UP/DOWN - change text size
LEFT/RIGHT - change amount of "jitter" (random offset for painting)
a - toggle AutoPaint (on/off)
1,2,3,4 - change color-source image
          stored as square "001.jpg" etc, in the data folder
g - paint a grid of text covering entire screen (may take a while in .js)
m/M - change paint Mode (the default mode takes color from images)
s - save
x - change black/white mode
c - clear screen

visuals.title: Creative Coding Final: Pointillism 花花
visuals.description:
This p5.js creative coding project is inspired by the 19th-century modern art movement -- Pointillism --a technique of painting in which small, distinct dots of color are applied in patterns to form an image. This project simulates an interactive exhibition experience, in which the user, together with the author,
recreates some of the most well-known Pointillism artwork with modern technology. The look of the final artwork not only depends on the code itself, but also the user's interactive control of
the size of the paint stroke.

visuals.title: Maze Generator: Randomized Kruskal's Algorithm迷宫
visuals.description:
Another maze generation program. This is one is a lot less fun than the last one but the code is a lot tidier and there is now a working solver. 

For more resources on Kruskal's algorithm, see:
* http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2011/1/3/maze-generation-kruskal-s-algorithm
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maze_generation_algorithm#Randomized_Kruskal's_algorithm
Basically, it puts the cells into sets, which are all merged (by removing a wall between them) until all the cells are connected. The colors you see are the sets.

Kruskal's algorithm generates perfect mazes with a uniform spanning tree.
visuals.instructions: Use the controls on the right. See description for more info.

Colors varies based on the area of the screen you are clicking (moving the mouse), the expanding speed and the maximum size of the shape are randomized.

visuals.title: Blue Mountains
visuals.description:
A mountain range landscape.

Inspired by lesson 38 of Fun Programming: http://funprogramming.org/38-Animate-the-ocean-surface-using-noise.html 

Colors chosen to work on Javascript (the clouds and the sky gradient look different on Java mode). Also, I don't know why, the lerpColor didn't work on Java, it's possible to get the same effect with separated map functions for hue, saturation and brightness though. - Barbara Almeida

Adjusted the mountains to start ~ 1/3 from the top. The rule of thirds is a good guide to where major divisions should lie in a painting or photograph. - Richard B
visuals.instructions:
Mouse click to generate a new pattern.
Press s to save as an image.

visuals.title: Interactive Painting

visuals.instructions: Click to paint, you will need a web camera.

visuals.title: ImageTexter
visuals.description:
A text-painter, with color coming (primarily) from 4 possible images.
Try painting a grid, reducing the size, and painting again!

UP/DOWN - change text size
LEFT/RIGHT - change amount of "jitter" (random offset for painting)
a - toggle AutoPaint (on/off)
1,2,3,4 - change color-source image
          stored as square "001.jpg" etc, in the data folder
g - paint a grid of text covering entire screen (may take a while in .js)
m/M - change paint Mode (the default mode takes color from images)
s - save
x - change black/white mode
c - clear screen

visuals.title: flockingTwo
visuals.description: Basic obstacle avoidance:  All boids are the same species.  First,  a broad check of boids near to,  but not necessarily contacting the obstacle,  and then a precise,  but more computationally expensive, line-point  intersection check,  to determine if there has been  actual contact.
visuals.instructions: Mouse click to reset and toggle between 2 modes.

visuals.title: Fluid Simulation + Momentum Transfer + Electrostatic Force
visuals.description:
Mouse-interactive fluid simulation with particles.
The fluid simulation is solved on a 16x16 cell grid.
Using Verlet integration for the particle update.
Every particle has an electric charge and two of them have a static value. When any two  particles collide, they equally share it. The border is the electric ground. There's a nonlinear friction and on every collision there's a tiny amount of 1% energy lost, so its passive state approaches a global lower limit energy.
So far, the binding of the forces is one-way only and the particle motion doesn't add to the fluid simulation.
Have fun!

visuals.title: 3D Plotter
visuals.description: A way to plot 3D graphs in the form "y = f(x) +f(z)".
visuals.instructions:
Mouse to look around. Box changes y-scale, UP arrow to "zoom in", DOWN arrow to "zoom out".

Note: you can use "x^2", but for nested powers use "pow(x^2, 2)". You can also use certain parts of programming, use "fc" for "frameCount" to make the sketches dynamic.

visuals.title: Game of Life
visuals.description: A simple processing implementation of Conway's game of life. The "game" is a zero-player game, meaning that its evolution is determined by its initial state, requiring no further input. One interacts with the Game of Life by creating an initial configuration and observing how it evolves Rules 1) Any live cell must have exactly two or three live neighbours to live 2) Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_Game_of_Life<;br>
visuals.instructions: Use the mouse to set cells alive giving them a black color. Press "space" to start the iteration process and "enter" to reset. Note that you can set cells alive during iterations

visuals.title: Spring force chain
visuals.description:
A series of springs are connected to each other to get a pendulum-like effect.

Inspired by Daniel Shiffman's The Nature of Code (shiffman.net)

Controls:
- Left & right click to add wind force
- Middle mouse click to increase gravity
- Q to increase springs elasticity
- W to decrease springs elasticity
- A to increase mass
- S to decrease mass
visuals.instructions: Check description.

visuals.title: Cloth mesh verlet integration
visuals.description:
Controls:
 - Left & right click to add wind force
 - Middle mouse click to increase gravity
 - Hold 'Q' to cut the cloth
 - Hold 'W' to paint areas to snap points
 - Hold 'E' to paint away areas to unsnap points
 - 'R' to reset the sim
 - 'T' to toggle between building triangulation
 - 'A' to increase timesteps
 - 'S' to decrease timesteps
 - 'Z' to decrease grid's resolution
 - 'X' to increase grid's resolution

visuals.title: Conway's Game of Life
visuals.description: My simple representation of Conway's game of life.
visuals.instructions: Mouse click to reset.

visuals.title: Solar system sketcher
visuals.description: Recursively creates a series of circles that orbit each other to form abstract patterns. Inspired by Barbara Almeida's Circles (www.openprocessing.org/sketch/211167)
visuals.instructions: Mouse click to reset.

visuals.title: Infinity rainbow
visuals.description:
Uses sine waves to create an infinity shape.

Controls:
  - Move mouse along width to change its count.
  - Move mouse along height to change its size.
visuals.instructions: Check description.

visuals.title: Pixel dust
visuals.description:
Uses particles to form an image.
When the mouse touches a particle, it activates and physics takes over.

Controls:
    - Move mouse on images to toss particles.
    - Space bar change to reset and change to the next image.
    - Z or X to change the target's size.
    - A or S to change the image's resolution.

If this is running too slow on your machine you can keep hitting s key to lower the resolution.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Accidental fractals
visuals.description:
While debugging another sketch, I realized I accidentally was able to create fractal patterns.
This is the result of digging deeper into it.

Controls:
- Mouse click to toggle between fill or stroke.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Blue wave
visuals.description:
Lots and lots of sine waves to create a giant sine wave.

Controls:
- Move the mouse across the width to change frequency.
- Move the mouse across the height to change amplitude.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Wide mouth
visuals.description:
Forms an image with particles, then scatters them from a pre-selected source to give an illusion of a wide mouth.

Inspired by a sketch I saw on Jacob Joaquin's awesome blog. (jacobjoaquin.tumblr.com)

If it's running too slow, keep pressing the S key to lower the resolution.

Controls:
- A or S to change the image's resolution.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Vector soft selection
visuals.description:
Using vectors aiming at the mouse to get a soft selection effect.

Controls:
- Move the mouse around.
- Hold A to increase selection size.
- Hold S to decrease selection size.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: 2d ragdoll
visuals.description:
Uses verlet integration to achieve a shoddy ragdoll.

Fast velocities breaks it pretty easily, but still think the overall effect is pretty neat.

Inspired by Keith Peters' tutorial (youtube.com/watch?v=3HjO_RGIjCU)

Controls:
- Click and drag any point from the ragdoll to move it.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Flow field waterfall
visuals.description: Particles are driven by a flow field until it reaches the yellow line. Then their dynamics are enabled and take over to make them fall. Inspired by Robert D'arcy's sketch Surfs up (www.openprocessing.org/sketch/298646) Controls: - Click to change to the next flow preset. - Move mouse along the width to set where gravity takes over.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Particles text effects
visuals.description:
Uses particles with a seek behavior to make up a word.

The word is loaded into memory so that each particle can figure out their own position they need to seek.

Inspired by Daniel Shiffman's arrival explantion from The Nature of Code. (natureofcode.com)

Controls:
    - Left-click for a new word.
    - Drag & right-click over particles to interact with them.
    - Press any key to toggle draw styles.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Heart beat
visuals.description:

visuals.title: Segment intersection study
visuals.description:
A study to determine the points of intersection between 2 segments.

The algorithm is by Gavin from SO (stackoverflow.com/questions/563198/how-do-you-detect-where-two-line-segments-intersect)

I only converted it over. I'm not smart enough to figure out the math myself.

Controls:
- Drag with left or right mouse buttons to move points.

More great reference from Keith Peters:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4bIsntTiKfM
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A86COO8KC58
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aqhn4REbK6c
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Enemy FOV with walls study
visuals.description:
Another study with FOV but now you can hide behind walls.

I used a few resources to get it at this point:
    - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=73Dc5JTCmKI
    - https://legends2k.github.io/2d-fov/design.html
    - http://ncase.me/sight-and-light/

Controls:
    - Click and drag end points of walls to move them.
    - Hold up & down arrow keys to adjust the fov's angle.
    - Press space to toggle debug drawing.

visuals.title: Obj viewer
visuals.description:
Reads data from an obj format and displays it.

An obj format is a generic format used by most 3d software packages to describe a mesh. In fact, this model was exported out from Maya.

There's so much more to be done with this, but here's a start!

Controls:
    - Drag left-click to rotate camera.
    - Drag middle-click to move camera.
    - Drag right-click to zoom.
    - E to toggle edges.
    - P to toggle points.
    - F to toggle faces.
visuals.instructions: Check the description.

visuals.title: Like!
visuals.description:
It may take a minute to load from all the resources it's loading.

This sketch works specifically for OpenProcessing.
It searches through the DOM to collect all users who liked this sketch and displays them.

Controls:
- Like this sketch then press f5 to refresh the *page* (not just the sketch). You will then show up here!

UPDATE:
With so many urls to go through, the sketch was taking a very long time to load. After adding a callback, it should now load fast!

Also added numbers beside each name to represent the order when it was liked.
visuals.instructions: Check description!

visuals.title: Fire brush 2 (sprites)
visuals.description:
Another attempt at fire and smoke using sprites.
 
Before I was controlling the image's transparency using 'tint', but this was slowing down the sketch way too much. Instead I'm creating new images in setup but with different transparencies that the sketch can reference to. This removes 'tint' from draw() and boosts the speed of it ten fold.

visuals.title: Coronavirus simulation
visuals.description:
Roughly simulates an outbreak using different social distances. The rules are simple: Sick people can only pass on sickness to healthy people, but with enough time they'll recover and be immune.

Play around with the variables at the top to explore how it can spread in different environments.

Inspired by this article:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/?fbclid=IwAR1tGUaApSRIXYCArDRx3kra6xkTNUkh4k4EWonp0d0XOvU2P9z7pVqiOcQ
visuals.instructions: Use the buttons on the bottom to reset.

visuals.title: Facial Rig
visuals.description:
A more extensive test to get a full blend shape facial rig working online.

I had to write a script in Maya to export poses consistently so that verts would blend without jumping around.

Each control captures 4 different states: Up, down, left, and right. When a control is moved, their deltas all applied to a mesh blending between them all to give the final output.

Good times!
visuals.instructions: Drag the points to deform his face

visuals.title: Art gallery painter (for NFT)
visuals.description:
Maps the image's brightness to determine the stroke's direction and the color's hue.

Mouse click to switch to the next image.

You can try your own image by editing the variable imgNames and the preload on line 1. Images that don't exceed 700px work best. It doesn't capture details well so close ups also work best.
visuals.instructions: Mouse click to switch to the next image.

visuals.title: wip
visuals.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:
  - Click to change to the next image.
  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.
visuals.instructions: Click for the next image, press a key to save a jpg.
